advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>"From 1 to 16 users"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color ="#666666">The Altos ACS8000-6 series. It's a barrier breaker in every sense. Our entry level, single-user, hard-disk system with floppy backup is priced under $10,000...<br> ... With MP/M at the helm, your Altos system can support up to four simulteneous users with 48 KB RAM each plus 58 MB of Winchester storage and 4 MB of floppy backup. And that adds up to the first microcomputer to give you the power and performance of a minicomputer.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert puts forward network capabilities of Televideo systems.<br><br><font color="#666666"> ... If you want a personal computer that gives you professional performances, it's obvious that you have a lot of choices for today.<br> But there's only one with choices for tomorrow. Televideo ...</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT JULY 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PC-60</strong></font><br><blockquote>Photo taken from a Commodore brochure.<br> Notice that the girl seems not to be interested at all in the computer...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>Two generations amazed...</b> <br><br> Perhaps a bit too much though... but the scene is beautiful and we can only admire the originality of the Philips' communication campaign which, for once, is not exclusively focused on the young Basic apprentices.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In U.K., at 1986 Christmas period, the 1040 STF was sold £799 + VAT for the 12" monochrome version, and £999 + VAT for the 14" colour version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Micromachine 4000 but a picture of the Micromachine 2000 and 3000 is inserted for reference...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> XEROX RANGE, AUGUST 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The Sinclair spirit is in him''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPARISON CHART</strong></font><br><blockquote>This document compares the different Panasonic systems of the serie<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 36 MHZ. IN 1982?</strong></font><br><blockquote>The title of this advert was very optimistic. In fact, the 36 Mhz speed is obtained by adding the speed of the 9 x Z80 cards installed into the system. The maximum system speed was in fact 4 Mhz.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert from Byte magazine (january 1977) said : <br><br> ...It gets its speed and power from a selected version of the new Z80 microprocessor that can operate at a 4 Mhz. clock rate (The Z-1 also lets you switch to 2 Mhz. to be compatible with older systems)...<br> ...The Z-1 offers you all kinds of peripherals and softwares. It uses the standard ''S100'' bus supported by over a dozen manufacturers. And all Cromemco peripherals (PROM memory and programmer, Ram memory, analog I/O, color TV interface, etc) just plug into the Z1's sockets...<br> ... The Z-1 comes completely assembled ans tested. It's a quality, commercial grade microcomputer. It is not available as a kit.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUSTAR AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Compustar standard features in 1983:<br> - 350 KB / 750 KB / 1.5 MB workstation disk capacities<br> - 10 to 144 MB storage options<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Compustar is built and backed by the company that's been in the microcomputer business as long as microcomputers have been in business. Would you trust your business to anything less?</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>We love this photo!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>April 1987 price list, including VAT.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (MAY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing pret-a-porter" <br><br> "Casio FX-702P : pocket Basic" <br><br> "Casio, it counts"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> What makes the QX-10 the most remarkably usable computer to date is a unique software system called VALDOC...<br><br> ... VALDOCS may be all the software you will never need. Right out of the box, it's a sophisticated <i>word processor</i>; an <i>information indexer</i> for easy acces to files; an <i>electronic mail system</i>;a <i>calculator</i>;an <i>apointment book</i> and <i>notepad</i>; and a <i>high resolution business graph drawing system</i>...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CREATIVITY BUILT-IN</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a French advert from december 1985 for a special christmas pack : TO-7/70 + Microsoft Basic level 5 + tape recorder + Colorpaint + Basic initiation cube for "only" 3990 FF. <br><br> "All the world in a present"</blockquote>

computer.description:
The Model 4P was the transportable version of the Model 4.
Apart from the case and display sizes, technical features were almost identical to the Model 4's. The dual half-sized floppy drives were still single-sided versions but the keyboard, which slided underneath the computer, was far better than the one of the desktop version.
The external floppy drive connector was removed, as well as the Model 3 ROM, but a ROM image could be loaded from diskette to run Model 3 programs. An optional 300-baud modem could be also installed into the machine.
Very late models had double-sided TEAC drives.
_______________________

emulator.description: This program emulates a complete TRS-80
emulator.name: David Keil's TRS-80 Model III/4/4P Emulator Page

emulator.description: This page offers shareware versions of a TRS-80 Model 4 emulator and a TRS-80 Model 1-2 emulator
emulator.name: Matthew Reed's TRS-80 Emulator Web Site

emulator.description: This TRS-80 Model III/4 Emulator is a commercial product
emulator.name: TRS-80 Model III/4 Emulator

emulator.description: xtrs is a Radio Shack TRS-80 Model I/III/4/4P emulator for Unix and the X Window System
emulator.name: xtrs: TRS-80 Model I/III/4 Emulator for Unix

emulator.description: With this Java emulator, you'll be able to write a BASIC program directly in your browser!
emulator.name: TRS-80 Level I BASIC in a browser

emulator.description: A complete list of TRS-80 emulators for various platforms !
emulator.name: Ira Goldklang's TRS-80 Revived Pages

emulator.description: MESS emulator also emulates a TRS-80 systems
emulator.name: MESS

item.description: Remote Unit Active|||Serial# 26-1210|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> REMOTE UNIT ACTIVE</strong></font><br><strong>> Serial# 26-1210</strong><br><blockquote>This rare unit is meant for teachers to control up to 16 TRS-80 Model 1 from a another TRS-80 equiped with min-disk. All the controled TRS-80 model 1 must be equiped with Level II. <br><br> It cost 2895fr (France, 1981)</blockquote>

Network II box|||p/n 26-1211|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> NETWORK II BOX</strong></font><br><strong>> p/n 26-1211</strong><br><blockquote>This box allowed up to 16 TRS computer to be networked. Three network boxes were released by Tandy (I, II and III).<br> The Network II required verbal communication between the server operator and the remote user, and data transfer had to be completed one user at a time.<br> The network III allowed automated control of the network so that users could easily access programs and data stored on the server's storage device.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>David Sutherland</b> for the pictures.</p></blockquote>

Daisy Wheel Printer II|||Serial# 26-1158|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> DAISY WHEEL PRINTER II</strong></font><br><strong>> Serial# 26-1158</strong><br><blockquote>This is a high-quality printer meant to be used with wordprocessors. Some interchangeable daisy-wheels were available (Courrier, Elite, Madeleine). It could print 163 characters per line (34cm), at a 43 cps rate. <br><br> It cost 9595fr (France, 1981)</blockquote>

Line Printer I |||Ref# 26-7017|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> LINE PRINTER I </strong></font><br><strong>> Ref# 26-7017</strong><br><blockquote>This printer was a custom version of the Oki Microline 80.<br> Printed lower and upper case on paper rolls or listing paper (24cm wide) from 40 to 80 columns/line, at a speed rate of 28 lines/minute. <br><br> It cost 716 Euros in 1981 (France).</blockquote>

Line Printer III|||Serial# 26-1156|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> LINE PRINTER III</strong></font><br><strong>> Serial# 26-1156</strong><br><blockquote>This printer can print lower and upper case, at a speed rate of 120 c/s, on paper up to 38cm wide. It is conceived for intensive use ! <br<<br> It cost 9950fr in 1981 (France). </blockquote>

Line Printer VI|||Serial# 26-1166|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> LINE PRINTER VI</strong></font><br><strong>> Serial# 26-1166</strong><br><blockquote>This large printer can print lower and upper case, graphic characters and symbols at a speed rate of 100 c/s ! This is definately a professional printer. <br><br> It cost 5495fr in 1981 (France).</blockquote>

Exatron |||Stringy Floppy drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> EXATRON </strong></font><br><strong>> Stringy Floppy drive</strong><br><blockquote>The Exatron Stringy Floppy (ESF) was a low-cost data—storage system that fitted the gap, between cassettes and disk drives.<br> The system was based on a miniature endless—loop tape cartridge called a "wafer".<br> The amount of data that could be recorded on a wafer depended on the length of tape in it, typically, a 50—foot wafer could hold at least 40 KB of programs or data. <br><br> <b>Matt</b> reports to us:<br><font color="#666666"> A curiousity about the model 1, CPU SPEED had a direct relatonship with STORAGE CAPACITY. if you doubled the clock speed of your MODEL 1 CPU you doubled the amount of data you could store on your stringy floppies. this is a feat that no other computer no matter how many ghz you have in your PC can do today without using compression.</font> <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>David Sutherland</b> for the pictures</p></blockquote>

computer.keyboard: Typewriter style, 70 keys with numeric keypad and arrow keys
computer.media: 2 x 5.25'' SS SD 180 KB floppy drives Very late models had double-sided TEAC drives
computer.name: TRS 80 Model 4P

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> BACK</strong></font><br><blockquote>from left to right: <br><br> - RS232C connector<br> - I/O bus<br> - parallel port<br></blockquote>
